cases.title: Gelyke Kanse and Others v Chairperson of the Senate of the University of Stellenbosch and Others
cases.snippet: This case concerned the decisions of the Senate and Council of the University of Stellenbosch to adopt a new language policy for the University (2016 Policy). The applicants approached the Constitutional Court to ask for the setting aside of the 2016 Policy on grounds that it violates section 29(2), and also contravenes other constitutional provisions, including section 6(2), section 6(4), the equality clause and other provisions of the Bill of Rights.
citedCases: Kanse v The President of the Convocation of the Stellenbosch University 2017 JDR 1687 (WCC)

cases.title: AfriForum and Another v University of the Free State
cases.snippet: This case was about whether the adoption of the language policy that discontinues the use of Afrkiaans as a primary medium of instruction, by the University of the Free State, is constitutionally valid and whether the University's policy is consistent with the Ministerial Language Policy Framework. AfriForum and Solidarity approached the Court as they believe that proper research was not conducted, and that most white and some black Afrikaans-speaking students prefer to be taught in Afrikaans. They see no justification for the language policy-shift.

cases.title: MEC for Education: KwaZulu-Natal and Others v Pillay
cases.snippet: This case concerned the right of a learner to wear a nose stud to school and whether the rule prohibiting the wearing of jewellery had the potential for indirect discrimination because it allowed certain groups of learners to express their religious and cultural identity freely, while denying that right to others.

cases.title: Economic Freedom Fighters v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others; Democratic Alliance v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others [2016] ZACC 11; 2016 (5) BCLR 618 (CC); 2016 (3) SA 580 (CC)
cases.snippet: The case concerned the legal status of the remedial powers that are vested in the Public Protector after the second respondent failed to comply with the remedial action taken against him. His argument lay in the fact that the Public Protector was not a judge and could not be afforded the same power to have binding remedial actions.

cases.title: Public Protector v South African Reserve Bank [2019] ZACC 29; 2019 (9) BCLR 1113 (CC); 2019 (6) SA 253 (CC)
cases.snippet: This case concerned the lawfulness of various search and seizure operations that were carried out at the officers of Mr Zuma's attorney and Thint, and at the residences and former offices of Mr Zuma. Messrs Zuma and Hulley and Thint applied to the Constitutional Court for an order for the return of their documents, arguing that Ngoepe JP should not have issued the warrants because the state failed to disclose various material facts. They argued that the warrants were overbroad and vague and effectively authorised an unbounded search of the relevant premises, contrary to their right to privacy in terms of section 14 of the Constitution. Finally, they asserted that Mr Zuma’s right to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege.

cases.title: Economic Freedom Fighters v Gordhan and Others; Public Protector and Another v Gordhan and Others [2020] ZACC 10; 2020 (8) BCLR 916 (CC)
cases.snippet: The Public Protector issued the SARS Report which directed the President to take note of the findings of maladministration, corruption and improper conduct and take appropriate disciplinary action against Mr Gordhan. Mr Gordhan launched an urgent application in the High Court on 10 July 2019 for an order temporarily suspending this remedial action and interdicting the Public Protector from enforcing it, pending the finalisation of a judicial review in which Mr Gordhan sought to set aside the SARS Report. This case concerned the appropriate test to be applied when granting interim interdicts against the Public Protector.

cases.title: Certification of the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, 1996
cases.snippet: The  Constitutional Court judgment was unique in the sense that it required the Constitutional Court to consider whether the constitutional text adopted by the Constitutional Assembly complied with the 34 constitutional principles in schedule four of the Interim Constitution.

cases.title: AB and Another v Pridwin Preparatory School and Others [2020] ZACC 12
cases.snippet: The issue in this case was whether the clause in the contract between the parents and the school was a Constitutionally valid one as it did not afford the other party to the contract to state their case before the contract was terminated. Secondly, whether independent schools had constitutional duties and obligations that limited their exercise of contractual rights

cases.title: The Citizen 1978 (Pty) Ltd and Others v McBride
cases.snippet: The key issue the Constitutional Court had to determine was how amnesty granted to the respondent for crimes committed (during the struggle against apartheid) by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission affected a claim for defamation.

cases.title: Port Elizabeth Municipality v Various Occupiers
cases.snippet: This case dealt with an eviction order which the unlawful occupiers believed to be invalid because of the Prevention of Illegal Eviction from and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act.

cases.title: Mkontwana v Nelson Mandela Metropolitan Municipality
cases.snippet: There were three cases before the court, and they were all concerned with the constitutional validity of laws that in effect burden owners in relation to consumption charges for water and electricity supplied to other people who occupy their immovable property.

cases.title: Thint (Pty) Ltd v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others, Zuma and Another v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others
cases.snippet: The National Director of Public Prosecution prosecuted Mr Zuma for corruption. The applicants argued that the warrants should have not been issued because the state failed to disclose various material facts. They also argued that Mr Zuma’s right to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege. I

cases.title:
Executive Council of the Western Cape Legislature and Others v President of the
Republic of South Africa and Others
cases.snippet: The matter arises from a dispute between the Executive Council of the Western Cape and the national government relating to the validity of amendments to the Local Government Transition Act. The applicants applied for direct access to the Constitutional Court for an order declaring amendments to the Transition Act, effected by the President in terms of Proclamations R58 and R59 and section 16A of the same Act unconstitutional.

cases.title: De Lange v Smuts NO and Others
cases.snippet: The appellant made an application for confirmation of an order made by the Cape of Good Hope High Court on the constitutional invalidity of section 66(3) of the Insolvency Act 24 of 1936 which authorized a person presiding over a creditors' meeting to imprison an unruly witness.

cases.title: S v Dodo
cases.snippet: The applicants applied for confirmation of the constitutional invalidity of section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 105 of 1997 by the Eastern Cape High Court under the provisions of section 172(2) of the Constitution. Challenge to section 51(1), read with section 51(3)(a) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, obliged High Courts to sentence people convicted of certain serious offences to life imprisonment, unless substantial and compelling circumstances justified the imposition of a lesser sentence.

topics.title: Section 1: Republic of South Africa
topics.snippet: Section one of the Constitution provides the founding values on which the Republic of South Africa is founded on.

topics.title: Section 2: Supremacy of the Constitution
topics.snippet: Section 2 of the Constitution provides that the Constitution is the “supreme law of the Republic; law or conduct inconsistent with it is invalid, and the obligations imposed by it must be fulfilled”.

topics.title: Section 3: Citizenship
topics.snippet: Section 3 of the Constitution stipulates that there is a common South African citizenship and that all citizens of South Africa are not only equally entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship but are also equally subject to the duties and responsibilities of citizenship.

topics.title: Section 4: National Anthem
topics.snippet: Section 4 of the Constitution provides that the national anthem of the Republic of South Africa is determined by proclamation.

topics.title: Section 5: National Flag
topics.snippet: Section 5 of the Constitution provides that the national flag of the Republic is black, gold, green, white, red and blue, as described and sketched in Schedule 1 to the Constitution.

topics.title: Section 6: Languages
topics.snippet: Section 6 of the Constitution recognises that the official languages of the Republic are Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, siSwati, Tshivenda, Xitsonga, Afrikaans, English, isiNdebele, isiXhosa and isiZulu.

topics.title: Section 7: Rights
topics.snippet: Section 7 of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights is a “cornerstone of democracy in South Africa”.

topics.title: Section 8: Application
topics.snippet: Section 8 of the Constitution stipulates that the Bill of Rights, Chapter 2 of the Constitution, applies to all law and binds the legislature, the executive, the judiciary and all organs of state.

topics.title: Section 9: Equality
topics.snippet: Section 9 of the Constitution protects the right to equality and it provides that everyone is entitled to equal protection and benefit of the law.

topics.title: Section 10: Human Dignity
topics.snippet: Section 10 of the Constitution recognises that everyone has the right to inherent dignity and the right to have their dignity respected and promoted.

topics.title: Section 11: Life
topics.snippet: Section 11 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to life and is an unqualified right.

topics.title: Section 12: Freedom and Security of the Person
topics.snippet: Section 12 of the Constitution not only affords everyone the right to freedom and security of the person but it also affords everyone the right to bodily and psychological integrity.

topics.title: Section 13: Slavery, Servitude and Forced Labour
topics.snippet: Section 13 of the Constitution provides that no one may be subjected to slavery, servitude or forced labour.

topics.title: Section 14: Privacy
topics.snippet: Section 14 of the Constitution not only guarantees everyone a general right to privacy but also provides protection against specific instances of privacy violations such as the right not to have one’s home searched, property seized and the right to the privacy of one’s communications.

topics.title: Section 15: Freedom of Religion, Belief and Opinion
topics.snippet: Section 15(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion.

topics.title: Section 16: Freedom of Expression
topics.snippet: Section 16(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of expression which not only encompasses freedom of the press, freedom to receive or impart information, freedom of artistic creativity but also academic and scientific freedom.

topics.title: Section 17: Assembly, Demonstration, Picket and Petition
topics.snippet: Section 17 of the Constitution protects the right to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket and to present petitions on the condition that they are held “peacefully and unarmed”.

topics.title: Section 18: Freedom of Association
topics.snippet: Section 18 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of association.

topics.title: Section 19: Political Rights
topics.snippet: Section 19 of the Constitution stipulates broad political rights such as the right to form a political party, the right to campaign for a political party and cause and it guarantees the right of every citizen to participate in free, fair and regular elections and to stand for public office if so elected.

topics.title: Section 20: Citizenship
topics.snippet: Section 20 of the Constitution stipulates that no citizen may be deprived of citizenship.

topics.title: Section 21: Freedom of Movement and Residence
topics.snippet: Section 21 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of movement and residence and stipulates that not only has every citizen the right to enter, remain and reside anywhere in the Republic but everyone also has the right to move freely and to leave the Republic.

topics.title: Section 22: Freedom of Trade, Occupation and Profession
Section 24: Environment
topics.snippet: Section 24 of the Constitution confirms that everyone has a right to an environment that is not “harmful to their health or well-being” and places a positive obligation on the State to protect the environment for the benefit of future and present generations.

topics.title: Section 25: Property Rights
topics.snippet: Section 25 of the Constitution, the property provision in the Bill of Rights has both protecting and reformative provisions and it is important to understand this balance.

topics.title: Section 27: Healthcare, Food, Water and Security
Section 28: Children
topics.snippet: Section 28 of the Constitution provides a range of rights to children, extending from the right to legal identity, such as the constitutional protection of a child’s right to a name and nationality to the right to parental care and the right to be protected from exploitative labour practices.

topics.title: Section 29: Education
topics.snippet: Section 29 of the Constitution provides for education rights and it stipulates that everyone has the right to basic education and to “further education, which the state, through reasonable measures, must make progressively available and accessible.”

topics.title: Section 30: Language and Culture
topics.snippet: Section 30 of the Constitution affords protection to the right to use one’s own language and to participate in the cultural life of one’s choice.

topics.title: Section 31: Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities
topics.snippet: Section 31 of the Constitution affords protection to cultural, religious or linguistic communities.

topics.title: Section 32: Access to Information
topics.snippet: Section 32 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to access to “any information held by the State” as well as “any information held by another person and that is required for the exercise or protection of any rights.”

topics.title: Section 33: Just Administrative Action
topics.snippet: Section 33 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to “administrative action that is lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair” and provides individuals with the right to claim relief where their rights have been adversely affected by administrative action.

topics.title: Section 34: Access to Courts
topics.snippet: Section 34 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to have a dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair public hearing before a court or where appropriate by another independent and impartial tribunal or forum.

topics.title: Section 35: Arrested, Detained and Accused Persons
topics.snippet: Section 35 of the Constitution specifically provides for the rights of arrested, detained and accused persons and the range of constitutional rights in this section will only be of application once a person falls into one of these categories.

topics.title: Section 39: Interpretation of Bill of Rights
